Background: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‚ÄëTech Collaboration

Section titled ‚ÄúBackground: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‚ÄëTech Collaboration‚Äù

On October 14, Oracle and AMD announced a plan to build an ultra‚Äëscale AI super‚Äëcluster. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) will begin deploying 50,000 AMD Instinct MI450 GPUs in Q3 2026, with further expansion expected through 2027 and beyond. This would make Oracle the first hyperscaler to adopt AMD‚Äôs newest GPUs at scale for external AI compute services. According to launch details, each MI450 provides up to 432 GB of HBM4 and 20 TB/s memory bandwidth, enabling models roughly 50% larger than the prior generation to fit fully in memory.

Oracle‚Äôs move targets the explosive growth in compute needs for next‚Äëgeneration AI models. Building on years of collaboration with AMD (OCI has offered MI300X services since 2024), Oracle aims to provide enterprise customers with a high‚Äëperformance, scalable platform for AI training and inference using an open architecture and the latest hardware.

Beyond technology, markets view this as a strategic play to seize share in the AI wave. Oracle increasingly positions AI as its cloud growth engine. CEO Safra Catz expects OCI revenue to surge 77% YoY to $18B this fiscal year and sees potential to reach $144B over the next four years. Against this backdrop, Oracle is tightening its partnership with AMD to pre‚Äëbuild next‚Äëgen AI infrastructure ‚Äî a move with major upside but meaningful execution and market risks.

GPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up

Section titled ‚ÄúGPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up‚Äù

Today, Nvidia supplies over 90% of high‚Äëperformance AI GPUs used globally. Most hyperscalers ‚Äî Google, Amazon, Microsoft ‚Äî train AI primarily on Nvidia GPUs and the CUDA software stack. However, rising demand for a second source and more open alternatives is creating opportunity for challengers like AMD.

AMD has invested heavily in data‚Äëcenter GPUs. Its Instinct line (e.g., MI250, MI300X) has been trialed in supercomputers and cloud, though historically lagging Nvidia on ecosystem depth and some performance metrics. The new MI450 is a step‚Äëchange in memory capacity and bandwidth, paired with the open ROCm stack, aiming to offer a competitive, more open alternative to Nvidia‚Äôs H100/H200.

Other chipmakers are also pursuing AI acceleration. Broadcom reportedly partnered with OpenAI on custom accelerators, sending Broadcom‚Äôs stock up ~10% on the news. Intel‚Äôs Gaudi series (via Habana) targets value with competitive price‚Äëperformance. The hardware landscape is diversifying as leading AI firms sign multi‚Äëvendor deals.

Price and supply are critical. Nvidia‚Äôs flagship H100 has traded at $30,000‚Äì$40,000 per unit (peaking higher during shortages). Reports suggest AMD has priced MI300 series more aggressively (around ~$10,000 for large customers). Intel markets Gaudi at roughly half the cost of Nvidia alternatives. Hyperscalers are incentivized to diversify for cost control, creating an opening for AMD ‚Äî though potentially at lower margins.

Bottom line: Nvidia remains dominant near term, but AMD‚Äôs technical progress and alliances should lift its share over the next few years.

Cloud Competition: Oracle‚Äôs Opportunities and Challenges

Section titled ‚ÄúCloud Competition: Oracle‚Äôs Opportunities and Challenges‚Äù

Oracle is a relative latecomer to cloud vs. AWS, Azure, and GCP. The AI surge, however, is a chance to move faster: many enterprises want to train large models and deploy generative AI but face tight GPU supply, high costs, and single‚Äëvendor risk on mainstream clouds. Oracle‚Äôs bet on massive AMD GPU clusters aims to differentiate with open standards and better price‚Äëperformance, while attracting multi‚Äëcloud customers who don‚Äôt want to rely on a single provider.

Oracle‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll‚Äëin on AI‚Äù strategy is already yielding big wins. Since 2023, Oracle has secured multiple multi‚Äëbillion‚Äëdollar AI cloud contracts. Market chatter has also suggested a five‚Äëyear, up‚Äëto‚Äë$300B agreement with OpenAI to co‚Äëbuild 4.5 GW of data‚Äëcenter capacity ‚Äî reportedly the largest cloud contract ever. While not officially disclosed, these reports spurred investor optimism; when the rumor emerged in September, Oracle‚Äôs stock jumped ~25% after hours.

Even setting giant deals aside, AI demand is driving OCI‚Äôs guidance higher: this year, Oracle raised its OCI growth outlook from 70% to 77%. Founder Larry Ellison said ‚ÄúAI changes everything,‚Äù and expects AI to materially expand cloud demand in coming years. On the application layer, Oracle plans ‚ÄúAI Database‚Äù offerings that integrate models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini directly into Oracle Database to simplify enterprise access ‚Äî a classic Oracle strength that could complement its underlying compute build‚Äëout.

Challenges remain. The Big Three clouds are not standing still: AWS continues to procure Nvidia GPUs and expand Trainium/Inferentia; Azure is tied closely with OpenAI and works with multiple silicon partners; Google has TPUs plus Nvidia options. Competing with established ecosystems and deep capital pools is hard. Meanwhile, buying 50,000 GPUs entails massive capex and technical risk; if AI demand slows or customers underutilize capacity, Oracle could be left with excess.

Net: Oracle‚Äôs AI‚Äëcloud push is a high‚Äërisk, high‚Äëreward wager ‚Äî one that could materially expand its cloud footprint and share price if executed well.

Near Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation

Section titled ‚ÄúNear Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation‚Äù

Into the next six months (through 1H 2026), Oracle and AMD shares should track sentiment and quarterly prints. Both have rallied strongly on AI narratives: by mid‚ÄëOctober, AMD shares were up ~85% YTD, near all‚Äëtime highs; Oracle was up ~80% YTD. AMD popped 24% in a day after announcing an OpenAI partnership, adding ~$63B in market cap ‚Äî a sign of heightened expectations around AMD‚Äôs AI trajectory.

Short term, that enthusiasm likely needs digestion. Some positives (e.g., Oracle‚ÄìAMD collaboration) are already priced in, and investors may wait for tangible results. Macro variables (rates, growth data) can also add volatility.

If AMD‚Äôs next couple of quarters show data‚Äëcenter momentum (e.g., MI300X traction), the AI story strengthens. But before MI450 volume ramps, revenue impact may remain limited and expectations‚Äëdriven, implying higher share‚Äëprice beta.

Net: expect range‚Äëbound trading at elevated levels, with newsflow (partnerships, product launches, conference commentary) driving swings until fundamentals catch up.

Midterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue

Section titled ‚ÄúMidterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue‚Äù

Looking 12 months out (into 2H 2026), Oracle‚ÄìAMD cooperation should start bearing fruit. Q3 2026 is the target window for Oracle‚Äôs MI450‚Äëbased super‚Äëcluster to come online and begin serving customers. That‚Äôs when early investment can begin converting to revenue:

‚Ä¢ For AMD: Deliveries of 50,000 MI450s would contribute significant sales. Its OpenAI partnership is slated to begin deployments (reportedly ~1 GW in late 2026, growing to ~6 GW over several years). Management and sell‚Äëside views suggest these mega‚Äëorders could add ‚Äútens of billions‚Äù in new revenue over time and boost EPS materially ‚Äî assuming successful production ramp and on‚Äëspec performance.

‚Ä¢ For Oracle: AI compute capacity will step up materially with MI450 clusters in production, complementing earlier MI300X/MI355X services. Key AI customer wins should begin to contribute. If rumored mega‚Äëdeals prove out, fiscal 2027 could see step‚Äëfunction growth, with the market likely to pre‚Äëprice part of that in 2026.

Execution and competition are the key risks: AMD must hit schedules and targets; Oracle must convert capacity into sticky workloads amidst aggressive rivals.

Long Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty

Section titled ‚ÄúLong Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty‚Äù

By ~2028, AI/GPU/cloud dynamics could look very different. The opportunity set is large, but so are the uncertainties:

‚Ä¢ AMD Upside: If partnerships execute, AMD could emerge as a major AI‚Äëaccelerator supplier by 2027‚Äì2028, with data‚Äëcenter GPUs becoming a multi‚Äëbillion‚Äëdollar pillar. In a bullish case, AMD could reach 20%‚Äì30% share in AI accelerators.

‚Ä¢ AMD Risks: Technology cycles are fast. Nvidia‚Äôs Blackwell (2025‚Äì2026) and potential advances (e.g., GPU+CPU+optical interconnects) may extend its lead. AMD must sustain heavy R&D to keep pace in architecture and software ecosystems.

‚Ä¢ Oracle Upside: If Oracle becomes a top‚Äëtier AI compute provider through deep wins with customers like OpenAI, its cloud scale and reputation could rise significantly by 2028.

‚Ä¢ Oracle Risks: The AI cloud could bifurcate into a few giants or devolve into price wars. If AWS/Azure extend leads, Oracle‚Äôs share gains could remain limited.

Opportunities and Risks: Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúOpportunities and Risks: Summary‚Äù

Key Opportunities

  1. Explosive AI demand expands the total addressable market.
  2. Flagship collaborations can lift market share and revenue visibility.
  3. A more diversified silicon ecosystem (beyond Nvidia) reduces single‚Äëvendor risk.
  4. Underlying business trends for both Oracle and AMD are favorable.

Key Risks

  1. Intense competition and fast product cycles.
  2. Execution risk (R&D, yield, delivery, software ecosystem).
  3. Macro and regulatory headwinds.
  4. Valuation and bubble risk after sharp rallies.

Conclusion: Stock‚ÄëPrice Outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Stock‚ÄëPrice Outlook‚Äù

Oracle and AMD are leaning into the AI infrastructure super‚Äëcycle. If they execute, both could convert surging compute demand and a more open, multi‚Äëvendor landscape into durable growth and shareholder returns. Over six months, sentiment and newsflow likely dominate. Over a year, delivery milestones and contract conversions become the key drivers. Over three years, the winners will be those who ship reliably at scale while maintaining strong ecosystems and cost profiles.

item.title: Q3 2025 U.S. Bank Earnings: Market Correlations and AI Outlook
item.content:encoded:
Key Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market‚Äù

Based on historical data from Oct 2020 through Oct 2025, U.S. bank stocks exhibit a pronounced positive correlation with the major indices. The daily‚Äëreturn correlation between the Financials ETF (XLF) and the S&P 500 is 0.789 ‚Äî a strong positive relationship. Practically, bank shares tend to move in tandem with the broader market, though the link is not perfect and retains some independence.

By comparison, the correlation between bank stocks and the Nasdaq is lower at 0.626, reflecting structural differences between Financials and the tech‚Äëheavy Nasdaq. Notably, the correlation between the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq is as high as 0.951, indicating very tight co‚Äëmovement between the two benchmarks.

Earnings‚ÄëSeason Impact Pattern

Section titled ‚ÄúEarnings‚ÄëSeason Impact Pattern‚Äù

Analyzing the bank‚Äëearnings windows across 21 quarters over the past five years (the 5 trading days before and after each earnings release) reveals a few consistent patterns:

Directional synchronicity

Section titled ‚ÄúDirectional synchronicity‚Äù

Following bank earnings, Financials and the S&P 500 moved in the same direction 71.4% of the time; the synchronicity rate with the Nasdaq was 66.7%. Bank earnings thus tend to exert a notable directional influence on the overall market.

Return characteristics

Section titled ‚ÄúReturn characteristics‚Äù

In the five trading days after earnings, Financials rose an average of 0.49%, slightly ahead of the S&P 500‚Äôs 0.09% and the Nasdaq‚Äôs ‚àí0.19%. Strong bank results typically provide the most direct uplift to the Financials sector, with a comparatively smaller spillover to tech.

Year‚Äëto‚Äëyear differences

Section titled ‚ÄúYear‚Äëto‚Äëyear differences‚Äù

The pattern varies by year. In 2022, post‚Äëearnings performance was the strongest (Financials gained an average of 2.47% over the 5 days following reports), while 2020‚Äì2021 and 2025 saw negative returns ‚Äî a reflection of shifting macro backdrops and sentiment.

Recent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction

Section titled ‚ÄúRecent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction‚Äù

From Oct 14‚Äì15, 2025, large banks including JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, and BlackRock reported Q3 results, broadly beating expectations. Highlights include:

  • JPMorgan: revenue +9% to $47.1B; net income +12% to $14.4B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +17%
  • Goldman Sachs: net income +37% to $4.1B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +42%; M&A advisory +60%
  • Citigroup: revenue +9% to $22.1B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +34%

Strength was driven primarily by resurgent investment‚Äëbanking activity and elevated trading. A record‚Äësetting quarter for equities and warming M&A supported the backdrop. Still, despite impressive prints, JPMorgan and Goldman shares fell 3.8% and 5.0% on the day, respectively ‚Äî a reminder that elevated expectations and valuation can cap near‚Äëterm reactions.

Five‚ÄëYear Context

Section titled ‚ÄúFive‚ÄëYear Context‚Äù

From Oct 2020 to Oct 2025, Financials (XLF) posted cumulative gains of 119.09%, outpacing the S&P 500‚Äôs 99.23% and the Nasdaq‚Äôs 104.70%. By year:

  • 2021: Financials led with +34.28%, aided by recovery momentum and rising‚Äërate expectations
  • 2022: broad declines; Financials ‚àí13.48%, still better than the Nasdaq‚Äôs ‚àí33.89%
  • 2023: tech rebound; the Nasdaq surged +44.52%, while Financials rose +9.56%
  • 2024‚Äì2025: Financials continued to outperform amid evolving rate dynamics

Outlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026

Section titled ‚ÄúOutlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026‚Äù

S&P 500 and Nasdaq targets

Section titled ‚ÄúS&P 500 and Nasdaq targets‚Äù

Street targets skew cautiously optimistic into year‚Äëend:

  • Goldman Sachs: S&P 500 YE target 6,800 (~2% upside vs. current), and 6,900 for 2026
  • JPMorgan: YE range 6,000‚Äì6,500, cautious stance
  • BMO Capital: 7,000 ‚Äî among the most bullish
  • Morgan Stanley: YE 6,500; warns U.S.‚ÄìChina trade escalation could drive an ~11% pullback

Analysts broadly see an expected ~8% Q3 earnings growth (which would mark a ninth consecutive quarter if achieved) as a core support. Fed easing expectations, AI‚Äëdriven tech growth, and corporate profit resilience sit behind the constructive bias.

Risks remain: the S&P 500 trades at 22.8x earnings ‚Äî above the 5‚Äëyr average (19.9x) and 10‚Äëyr average (18.6x). Market cap concentration is elevated: roughly 40% sits in 10 ‚Äúsuper‚Äëstocks,‚Äù leaving less margin for error if leaders stumble.

AI Sector Deep Dive

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Sector Deep Dive‚Äù

AI leaders should continue to drive index performance, though growth rates likely moderate from prior peaks:

NVIDIA

Section titled ‚ÄúNVIDIA‚Äù

FY2025 revenue reached $130.5B, up 114% y/y, with Q4 revenue at $39.3B. FY2026 Q1 revenue was $44.1B (+69% y/y, decelerating). The Blackwell architecture contributed ~$11B in Q4 revenue ‚Äî dubbed the ‚Äúfastest product ramp‚Äù in NVIDIA‚Äôs history. Consensus points to FY2026 revenue around $198.8B and EPS of $4.32. Despite slower growth, NVIDIA retains ~80% share in AI accelerators.

Microsoft

Section titled ‚ÄúMicrosoft‚Äù

In FY2025 Q4, Azure‚Äôs annualized revenue run‚Äërate topped $75B (+39% y/y). The company guides record ~$30B capex in FY2026 Q1 for AI infrastructure. Intelligent Cloud is expected to grow 25‚Äì26%, with Azure (ex‚Äësome items) at ~37%. Microsoft Copilot MAUs surpassed 100M. Some analysts expect Microsoft could become the first $5T company.

Google and Amazon

Section titled ‚ÄúGoogle and Amazon‚Äù

Google Cloud Q2 revenue was $13.6B (+32% y/y), with a 20.7% operating margin; GCP (infrastructure) is estimated growing near 40%. AWS Q2 revenue was $30.9B (+17.5% y/y) but supply‚Äëconstrained. Anthropic is a flagship customer, and AWS is building >1 GW of data‚Äëcenter capacity to support AI demand.

Capex trends

Section titled ‚ÄúCapex trends‚Äù

The turning point: analysts expect cloud capex growth to slow meaningfully in 2026. Goldman sees growth stepping down from 54% (2025) to 26%; Morgan Stanley to 16%; Evercore to 18%. The deceleration reflects rising depreciation and return‚Äëpressure. Amazon and Google are expected to decelerate the most (~11% slower), while Meta may sustain ~42% growth.

AI market size

Section titled ‚ÄúAI market size‚Äù

The global AI market is projected to grow from $294.2B in 2025 to $1.77T by 2032 (29.2% CAGR). That underpins a durable multi‚Äëyear theme, but in the near term investors should watch how capex deceleration affects AI‚Äëinfrastructure valuations.

Investment Implications and Risks

Section titled ‚ÄúInvestment Implications and Risks‚Äù

Banks

Section titled ‚ÄúBanks‚Äù

Large banks delivered strong Q3 2025 prints, with trading and investment‚Äëbanking as key drivers. However, ongoing Fed cuts could compress net interest margins, weighing on traditional lending profitability. Bank CEOs remain cautious, flagging tariff uncertainty, geopolitics, and consumer credit quality.

AI equities

Section titled ‚ÄúAI equities‚Äù

While AI remains the long‚Äëterm growth engine, consider:

  1. stretched valuations leave limited error tolerance;
  2. slower capex growth could prompt multiple compression in AI infrastructure;
  3. concentration risk around a handful of mega caps.

Diversification into non‚Äëmega‚Äëcap beneficiaries (e.g., AMD, Palantir, select cloud providers) may be a more balanced approach.

Macro risks

Section titled ‚ÄúMacro risks‚Äù

U.S.‚ÄìChina tensions, U.S. government shutdown risk, sticky inflation, and slowing growth could raise volatility. Seasonally, Q4 often brings choppier tape ‚Äî stay alert.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

History suggests bank‚Äëearnings seasons align positively with the broader U.S. market; strong bank prints often support risk appetite. The latest October reports again broadly beat, underscoring sector resilience in today‚Äôs macro mix.

Into the next quarter, we expect modest gains for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, constrained by elevated valuations and macro uncertainty. AI should continue to lead, but with slower growth and capex normalization ‚Äî making selectivity more important and blind chasing of richly valued mega caps less prudent.

Financials have outperformed over the past five years, but 2026 could test durability amid a rate‚Äëcut cycle. Balanced portfolios ‚Äî blending cyclical Financials and secular AI winners while monitoring earnings quality and valuation ‚Äî look prudent.

Note: This report is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; proceed with caution.

GitHub has brought their ‚Äúhands-on‚Äù Copilot coding agent into the command line, capable of reading your repository, understanding issues/PRs, and executing step-by-step with your confirmation. Introduction: Why CLI?

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: Why CLI?‚Äù

We spend 80% of our coding time in the terminal. Can we bring ‚Äúplanning and executing‚Äù AI into the command line to reduce context switching? GitHub‚Äôs answer: Copilot CLI. 1. What‚Äôs Actually New?

Section titled ‚Äú1. What‚Äôs Actually New?‚Äù

1) Terminal Native, One Command to Start

Section titled ‚Äú1) Terminal Native, One Command to Start‚Äù

2) GitHub Ecosystem Integration

Section titled ‚Äú4) MCP Extensible‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú5) Model Upgrade Benefits‚Äù

  1. Install
  1. Login (follow interactive GitHub authentication)

Section titled ‚Äú3. How I Use It Daily: 6 High-Frequency Scenarios‚Äù

Commands in scenarios are examples; follow actual CLI prompts.

1) Understanding Unfamiliar Repositories

Suggested Visual: Issue ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Test ‚Üí PR arrow flow.

3) Local Debugging + Error Explanation

Section titled ‚Äú3) Local Debugging + Error Explanation‚Äù

Goal: Quickly locate mysterious errors. Approach: Have it read logs, combine with source code to provide reproduction scenarios and fix suggestions, generate minimal reproduction scripts. Benefit: Solve ‚Äúunderstand the error but don‚Äôt know where to start‚Äù anxiety.

4) Auto-Complete Missing Unit Tests

Section titled ‚Äú4) Auto-Complete Missing Unit Tests‚Äù

Goal: Fill gaps in critical path unit testing. Approach: Scan low-coverage areas, draft test cases, run local tests and auto-correct minor errors. Benefit: More stable quality gates, no blame for regressions.

5) ‚ÄúMajor Refactoring Week‚Äù Babysitting

Section titled ‚Äú5) ‚ÄúMajor Refactoring Week‚Äù Babysitting‚Äù

Goal: Cross-module refactoring, dependency upgrades, style unification. Approach: Leverage GPT-5-Codex long-chain reasoning for refactoring plans, batch process by subtasks, every step reversible. Benefit: Break high-risk changes into small, controllable progress.

6) Internal Tool Integration (MCP Extensions)

Section titled ‚Äú6) Internal Tool Integration (MCP Extensions)‚Äù

Goal: Make CLI work with your wiki/ticketing/build platforms. Approach: Integrate custom MCP Server, delegate ‚Äúsearch wiki, create tickets, trigger pipelines‚Äù to it. Benefit: Private knowledge + private processes work together, completely reduce context switching.

4. Division of Labor with ‚ÄúCloud Agents‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú4. Division of Labor with ‚ÄúCloud Agents‚Äù‚Äù
  • Copilot Coding Agent (Cloud): Can open cloud environments, long-running tasks, cross-repo operations, now GA.
  • Copilot CLI (Local): Close to your terminal for ‚Äúquick wins,‚Äù better for iterative development. Combination: Cloud handles heavy lifting, local does iteration and confirmation, both efficient and controllable.

5. Four Team Implementation Suggestions

Section titled ‚Äú5. Four Team Implementation Suggestions‚Äù
  1. Start with Security & Audit Processes: Write ‚Äúconfirmation required for each step‚Äù into team guidelines.
  2. Templatize Common Tasks: Like ‚Äúfix ESLint errors, add tests, generate changelogs.‚Äù
  3. Use MCP for Internal Integration: Start with read-only access, add write permissions after maturity.
  4. Model Strategy: Enable GPT-5-Codex when available, more obvious benefits for refactoring/migration.

6. Quick Start Checklist (Paste into README)

Section titled ‚Äú6. Quick Start Checklist (Paste into README)‚Äù
  • npm i -g @github/copilot install and login

  • Choose 1 pilot repository: limited permissions + enable ‚Äúconfirmation for each step‚Äù
  • Run 3 tasks first: read repository, fix one issue, add 1 test suite
  • Team retrospective: record time saved, failure cases, process improvements
  • MCP integration with 1 internal system, read-only first then read-write

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

CLI isn‚Äôt just another ‚Äúfancy interface‚Äù. It brings Agents to ‚Äúwhere you work every day.‚Äù When AI can understand context and execute step-by-step with your confirmation, the development rhythm changes: you make decisions, it handles the heavy lifting.

This methodology specifically addresses three major pain points: ‚ÄúAI can write code but doesn‚Äôt understand HarmonyOS,‚Äù ‚ÄúArkTS keeps throwing errors,‚Äù and ‚Äúregression testing can‚Äôt keep up.‚Äù The core principle: Drive Claude Code with documentation, and secure quality through BDD automation.

Introduction: Don‚Äôt Chat Randomly with AI ‚Äì Write Good Documentation First

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: Don‚Äôt Chat Randomly with AI ‚Äì Write Good Documentation First‚Äù

Many developers immediately tell AI: ‚ÄúHelp me build a HarmonyOS app for Bluetooth scanning, connecting, and time synchronization.‚Äù The result? Claude Code produces seemingly sophisticated code that turns completely red upon compilation. Are you familiar with ArkTS? Do you understand the ArkUI lifecycle? How do you handle regression testing? All uncertain.

HarmonyOS officially provides ArkTS coding standards, ArkUI declarative development paradigms, and performance practices ‚Äì these are standard components that Claude Code ‚Äúcrashes repeatedly if not learned properly.‚Äù ArkTS is HarmonyOS‚Äôs primary language, sharing roots with TypeScript but having its own semantics and ecosystem. Writing with old JavaScript habits makes it easy to fall into traps. The good news is: Claude Code already supports ‚Äúreading repositories, editing files, writing and running tests, executing terminal commands.‚Äù As long as you provide the right context, it can consistently produce engineered results.

I. Documentation-Driven Programming: Make Claude Code Follow Your Lead

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Documentation-Driven Programming: Make Claude Code Follow Your Lead‚Äù

Objective: Clearly explain requirements, value, implementation, and acceptance criteria on one page; let Claude Code ‚Äúbuild according to specifications‚Äù within the HarmonyOS context.

1) Write ‚ÄúOne-Page‚Äù Requirements (can be directly placed in repository /docs/feature-xxx.md)

Section titled ‚Äú1) Write ‚ÄúOne-Page‚Äù Requirements (can be directly placed in repository /docs/feature-xxx.md)‚Äù

  • Functionality: Bluetooth device scanning ‚Üí list display ‚Üí connection ‚Üí time synchronization ‚Üí status reading ‚Üí command sending ‚Üí disconnection

  • Business Value: Store associates complete device initialization in 1 minute, reducing manual errors by 80%

  • Platform: HarmonyOS NEXT, ArkTS + ArkUI; DevEco Studio build

  • Interface/Model: Device names start with XX; display battery level after connection; ‚Äúinjection‚Äù command returns success flag

  • Acceptance Criteria (BDD format):

    • Given Application is on the home page
    • When Click ‚ÄúStart Scan‚Äù, see device starting with XX in list and click Connect
    • Then Enter connected page, see device name/battery level; clicking ‚ÄúSync Time,‚Äù ‚ÄúRefresh Status,‚Äù ‚ÄúSend Injection Command‚Äù all return success

Remember to include key ArkTS/ArkUI constraints and best practices in documentation: naming, state management, performance considerations, etc. (from official style guides and state management guidelines). Provide specifications directly to Claude Code ‚Äì it will follow these rules during generation.

2) Initial System Prompt for Claude Code (place in .claude/primer.md)

Section titled ‚Äú2) Initial System Prompt for Claude Code (place in .claude/primer.md)‚Äù
  • Project framework (ArkUI page structure, directory conventions)
  • ArkTS code style requirements (variable/component naming, null checks, error handling)
  • Component inventory & event flow (Button ‚Üí scanning ‚Üí list ‚Üí connection)
  • Test-first approach: Generate BDD scenarios and ArkTS test stubs first, then supplement business code
  • Failure retry: compilation error ‚Üí read error ‚Üí modify minimal set only

Officials and community both emphasize standards-driven coding, which significantly reduces rework and performance issues. Claude Code itself also recommends customizing context and environment (e.g., ignoring irrelevant files, providing dedicated README/CONTRIBUTING), which can significantly improve hit rates.

3) Place ‚ÄúProcess Description + Acceptance Steps‚Äù in README

Section titled ‚Äú3) Place ‚ÄúProcess Description + Acceptance Steps‚Äù in README‚Äù

The image below shows our manual acceptance steps for this feature, used for manual verification and providing context for Claude Code:

This text will be absorbed by Claude Code as ‚Äúexecutable documentation‚Äù: it can write UI flows first, then supplement logic and tests (Claude officially claims to ‚Äúwrite and run tests, edit files, commit code‚Äù).

II. BDD Business-Driven Testing: Transform ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù into ‚ÄúExecutable Specifications‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúII. BDD Business-Driven Testing: Transform ‚ÄúDocumentation‚Äù into ‚ÄúExecutable Specifications‚Äù‚Äù

In one sentence: Write requirements as Gherkin scenarios, run tests on DevEco/arkXtest framework, test red ‚Üí AI fix ‚Üí test green again.

1) Describe Business with Gherkin

Section titled ‚Äú1) Describe Business with Gherkin‚Äù

The advantage of Gherkin/BDD is transforming ‚Äúbusiness language‚Äù directly into executable specifications, continuously validating whether system behavior matches documentation.

2) ArkTS Testing Implementation Selection

Section titled ‚Äú2) ArkTS Testing Implementation Selection‚Äù
  • DevEco/arkXtest System: Provides unified framework for unit testing + UI testing + performance testing; UI test scripts execute on top of unit tests, meeting end-to-end validation needs.
  • IDE Support: DevEco Studio integrates testing framework and code test entry points, facilitating execution on real devices/simulators.

Some documentation also mentions HarmonyOS/ArkTS testing capability upgrades in the NEXT version, supporting more modern syntax and parameterization techniques, which can be adopted in your engineering templates as needed (based on official and authoritative sources).

3) Example: UI Scenario Test Framework (extracted from actual project structure)

Section titled ‚Äú3) Example: UI Scenario Test Framework (extracted from actual project structure)‚Äù

This test does three things:

  1. If not scanned, try clicking ‚ÄúStart Scan,‚Äù otherwise log and skip
  2. Wait for device discovery
  3. Locate device with specified prefix and click connect, assert entry to connected page

This type of UI test case structure aligns with arkXtest‚Äôs design philosophy: drive UI operations with APIs, consolidate results uniformly in the testing framework.

4) Make ‚ÄúTest Red ‚Üí AI Fix ‚Üí Test Green Again‚Äù a Pipeline

Section titled ‚Äú4) Make ‚ÄúTest Red ‚Üí AI Fix ‚Üí Test Green Again‚Äù a Pipeline‚Äù
  • Claude Code Loop: When failures occur, paste compilation/runtime logs back into conversation for minimal modification fixes (Claude‚Äôs official ‚Äúenvironment tuning + context minimization‚Äù recommendations are crucial here).
  • IDE/CI Integration: One-click execution in DevEco Studio locally; CI integration with real devices/simulators for regression (refer to DevEco test entry points and official testing documentation).
  • Visual Acceptance: Place the manual acceptance step diagrams above in wiki, run Gherkin + UI tests for each version, ensuring ‚Äúdocumentation is truth.‚Äù

III. Implementation Manual: 7-Step Checklist from 0 to 1

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Implementation Manual: 7-Step Checklist from 0 to 1‚Äù

Step 1 | Project Initialization

  • Create ArkTS project in DevEco Studio; select ArkUI declarative paradigm; confirm target API/device.
  • Recommend pulling ArkTS style guide and performance practices into repository /guides for both human and AI reference.

Step 2 | One-Page Requirements

  • Clearly write functionality, value, interfaces, states, exceptions, acceptance scenarios (Given/When/Then).
  • Place screenshot-style manual acceptance steps in README (the diagram section above).

Step 3 | Claude Code Startup

  • Use .claude/primer.md and /docs as primary context; limit it from reading irrelevant large files.
  • Have it generate test stubs & Gherkin first, then supplement business code and ArkUI pages.

Step 4 | ArkTS/ArkUI Coding

  • Follow naming, componentization, state management constraints; pay attention to performance practices and null/exception handling.

Step 5 | Test Implementation

  • Use arkXtest / DevEco testing for unit tests + UI tests; use Gherkin as top-level use case description (can call UI test APIs in step definitions).

Step 6 | Iterative Fixes

  • Feed failure logs to Claude Code for minimal fixes; loop locally/CI until all green.

Step 7 | Knowledge Base Accumulation

  • Record pitfalls & FAQ in /kb: such as BLE permissions, lifecycle, list performance.
  • Next time, only need to modify ‚Äúone-page‚Äù requirements and a few step descriptions, Claude Code can reuse context to continue generation.

IV. Results: Quality, Speed, and Understanding ‚Äì Triple Success

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Results: Quality, Speed, and Understanding ‚Äì Triple Success‚Äù
  • Speed: With the ‚Äúdocumentation as code‚Äù approach, Claude Code is more stable on HarmonyOS projects, reducing back-and-forth guessing.
  • Quality: arkXtest + DevEco testing aligns unit tests/UI/performance, automates regression, leaving manual work for exploratory validation only.
  • Understanding: Standards and performance practices written in documentation, humans and AI follow the same rules, new team members can master ArkTS/ArkUI basics in 1 day.

V. Replicable Template (You Can Copy Directly)

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Replicable Template (You Can Copy Directly)‚Äù

Recommended Documentation Directory

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Documentation Directory‚Äù

feature-ble-connect.md Fragment

Section titled ‚Äúfeature-ble-connect.md Fragment‚Äù
  • Background/Value
  • Constraints (API/permissions/device prefix)
  • Acceptance Scenarios (5-7 Given/When/Then items)
  • Rollout/rollback strategy

Conclusion: Close the Loop Between ‚ÄúDocumentation‚ÄîTesting‚ÄîCode‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Close the Loop Between ‚ÄúDocumentation‚ÄîTesting‚ÄîCode‚Äù‚Äù

When you write documentation that can directly accept, Claude Code has the possibility to write correct ArkTS on the first try; When you get BDD scenarios running, each version can have one-click regression. This is how we consistently achieve ‚Äúfaster speed + more stable quality‚Äù in HarmonyOS projects.

What do you think this approach is still missing? Share your scenarios in the comments.

item.title: Outperforming the Market for Everyday Investors: The 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy with S&P 500, Nasdaq 100, and VGT
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR

Section titled ‚ÄúTL;DR‚Äù
  • Allocate your portfolio across three U.S. stock index funds using a 5:2:1 ratio (S&P 500 : Nasdaq 100 : Information Technology Sector).
  • Adhere to a long-term holding strategy with periodic rebalancing, dynamically fine-tuning based on capital size, return objectives, and risk tolerance.

A successful investor owes 85% to correct asset allocation, 10% to the skill of selecting investment targets, and 5% to the grace of God. ‚Äî William F. Sharpe

Long-term investing follows the principle of ‚Äúsimplicity is the ultimate sophistication‚Äù: ordinary investors can achieve substantial asset growth simply by holding one or two U.S. stock index funds over the long run. As a composite index of the 500 largest companies by market capitalization in the U.S. stock market, the S&P 500 covers major industries such as information technology, consumer discretionary, financials, and healthcare, and is widely regarded as a barometer of the overall performance of the U.S. stock market. For instance, the legendary investor Warren Buffett has repeatedly recommended S&P 500 index funds and stipulated in his will that 90% of his personal assets be invested in them, demonstrating his confidence in the index‚Äôs long-term, stable returns.

However, an S&P 500 index fund is not the only option. Depending on their risk appetite, investors can also add a Nasdaq 100 index fund and an information technology sector fund (VGT) to construct a ‚Äútripod‚Äù portfolio of U.S. stock index funds. Below, we introduce these three types of index funds worthy of long-term holding and explain how to allocate them according to a 5:2:1 ratio.

S&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Market

Section titled ‚ÄúS&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Market‚Äù

The S&P 500 Index is composed of the 500 largest U.S. public companies by market capitalization, spanning a wide range of sectors from technology and consumer goods to energy and utilities. Due to its diversified components and dispersed weights, the S&P 500 index fund is often considered the primary core asset for investing in the U.S. stock market. Historical data shows that the S&P 500 has a long-term annualized return of around 10%, with relatively moderate volatility, making it suitable for most investors seeking stable growth.

Advantages

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvantages‚Äù
  • Diversification: Covering 500 companies, it does not rely on individual stocks, thus fully diversifying unsystematic risk. The index components account for the vast majority of the U.S. stock market‚Äôs capitalization, effectively allowing one to ‚Äúbuy the U.S. economy in one click.‚Äù
  • Long-term Stable Growth: It has consistently reached new highs through multiple bull and bear cycles, with a high probability of achieving positive returns over long rolling periods.
  • Endorsement by Investment Masters: Many investment gurus advocate for regular investment in S&P 500 index funds; Buffett has long recommended a ‚Äúbuy and hold‚Äù strategy.

It is important to note that S&P 500 index funds are still subject to periodic drawdowns due to economic cycles, but their volatility risk is lower compared to narrower-based indices. For investors with average risk tolerance, an S&P 500 index fund can serve as a single, lifelong holding.

Nasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leaders

Section titled ‚ÄúNasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leaders‚Äù

The Nasdaq-100 Index consists of the 100 largest non-financial companies listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market and is renowned for its high weighting in technology stocks. The index includes tech giants such as Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet (Google‚Äôs parent company), Amazon, and Nvidia. By providing concentrated exposure to high-growth sectors, the Nasdaq-100 has delivered a significantly higher annualized total return than the S&P 500 over the past few decades.

The characteristics of a Nasdaq 100 index fund can be summarized as follows:

  • Heavy Allocation to Tech Growth: A high proportion of high-growth sectors like information technology results in long-term returns that often outperform the broader market.
  • Higher Volatility: High returns are accompanied by high volatility, with more severe drawdowns during market downturns (e.g., the periods of 2000‚Äì2002 and 2022).
  • Bias Towards Emerging Industries: Components are predominantly from fields like technology, communication services, and consumer discretionary, aligning with future trends but exhibiting weaker defensive capabilities.

In summary, the Nasdaq 100 index fund offers an opportunity to share in the growth of America‚Äôs leading technology companies. Its excellent long-term returns come with greater short-term volatility, making it suitable for investors with a certain level of risk tolerance who can withstand significant fluctuations in net asset value.

Information Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industry

Section titled ‚ÄúInformation Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industry‚Äù

Information technology sector funds focus on investing in the IT industry. Take Vanguard‚Äôs Information Technology ETF (ticker: VGT) as an example: VGT tracks the MSCI US IMI Information Technology 25/50 Index, holding over 300 IT company stocks, including large-cap tech firms like Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft, and Broadcom, as well as numerous small and mid-cap tech companies. Similar to the Nasdaq 100, VGT is highly concentrated in the technology sector but offers broader coverage (not limited to Nasdaq-listed companies).

The purpose of including an IT sector fund in a portfolio is to capture the excess returns of the technology industry. Over the past decade, VGT has at times outperformed the Nasdaq 100, as small and mid-cap tech stocks contributed additional gains during tech booms. However, higher returns come with higher risks. The tech sector is often the first to be hit during interest rate hikes or market panics, and pure-tech ETFs experience larger drawdowns in volatile markets. During the 2022 tech bear market, VGT‚Äôs maximum drawdown was nearly -35%, slightly higher than the Nasdaq 100‚Äôs maximum drawdown during the same period.

This type of fund is more suitable for investors who are highly optimistic about the future of technology and have a strong personal risk tolerance. For those who have already achieved financial freedom or are experienced investors, a moderate allocation to pursue higher returns is feasible. However, ordinary investors with lower risk appetites can choose not to allocate to it or to reduce their allocation.

The 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancing

Section titled ‚ÄúThe 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancing‚Äù

For the three types of index funds discussed above, a straightforward portfolio strategy is to allocate them in a 5:2:1 ratio: approximately 62.5% to the S&P 500, 25% to the Nasdaq 100, and 12.5% to an information technology sector fund. The philosophy is as follows:

  • Core Holding (approx. 50%): The S&P 500 provides a stable foundation and broad diversification, capturing the average growth of the U.S. economy.
  • Satellite Holding (approx. 20%): The Nasdaq 100 enhances the portfolio‚Äôs long-term returns, sharing in the growth of large-cap tech.
  • Aggressive Holding (approx. 10%): The IT sector fund increases aggressiveness, providing greater elasticity during favorable economic cycles.

This portfolio balances stability and aggressiveness and can be fine-tuned according to individual circumstances. For example, conservative investors can reduce the weighting of the Nasdaq and tech funds (e.g., to 7:2:1 or 8:1:1), while aggressive investors can moderately increase the aggressive portion. The portfolio should be periodically rebalanced based on market changes and financial goals to restore the asset weights to their preset levels, thereby maintaining the desired risk-return profile.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

The S&P 500, Nasdaq 100, and information technology sector funds can form a three-pronged portfolio for long-term holding, combining a comprehensive and stable core with a high-growth engine that capitalizes on the technology wave. By adopting an appropriate allocation ratio based on their risk tolerance, and by adhering to a long-term investment strategy with periodic rebalancing, most investors can expect to achieve favorable risk-adjusted returns, fostering long-term wealth appreciation. Instead of frequent market timing and stock picking, it is more effective to build a simple and efficient index fund portfolio and hold it for the long term, navigating through bull and bear markets.
